alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Allagash Saison is our interpretation of a classic Belgian farmhouse style. It is a golden hued beer, brewed with a 2-Row blend, malted rye, oats and dark Belgian candi sugar. It was hopped with Tettnang, Bravo and Cascade hops. Fermented with a traditional saison yeast strain, this beer exhibits notes of spice and tropical fruit in the aroma. Citrus and a peppery spice dominate the flavor and make way for a pleasant malts

# What You Should Know

What is a Saison? Well, moyens de Saison en fran√ßais\* (what Saison means in French) is "season", and Saisons were originally brewed in Belgium on farms for summer drinking. The beer would be brewed in the fall or winter to employ unoccupied farm workers and provide beer for seasonal laborers in the summer. Traditionally, these SaIsons would have strong yeast flavors but a crisp, light color. Originally, the Saisons would have had lower ABVs, in the 1900s the alcohol content started to creep up to 5%-7%. Today, there is great variety in what constitutes a Saison, but almost are extremely dry but still malty. Oh, and they are cool. Really cool. So there's that.

\*Note: this translation was definitely taken from Google Translate. Our apologies if makes no sense whatsoever.

# The Boys' Take

Man, Allagash sure does make good beer. This one is easy on the eyes (being a nice clear yellow) and in the mouth. It's gonna be dry, but very crisp and refreshing. Saisons can seem strange or confusing to the uninitiated, but don't be scared. They all (and especially this one) have a lot to offer!

# About the Brewer

Allagash is your serious Belgian brewery, and was one of the first (founded in 1994). Located in Portland, Maine (that's right, the other Portland), Allagash isn't flashy. But owner Rob Tod is committed to his craft, and if you like Belgians, man their beers are good. You're only going to find traditional recipes at this brewery, and a lot of beers that only get better with age. Why is this? Well, Allagash beers (similar to many styles of Belgian beer) are actually fermented twice. After the initial fermentation and bottling, more yeast and sugar are actually added, meaning Allagash beers are typically more carbonated and complex than other beers. Because of the added yeast, the flavor will continue changing, meaning after a few months, your may be totally different!

# Drink this if You Like

Belgian beer, Pale ales, Wheat beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Farmhouses, Belgium, a beer earned with manual labor

# Drink While You Are

On the farm, cooling off after a long day

# Pair With

Asian, Farmhouse Food, Red Meat, French Cuisine

alcohol.name: Saison

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Most breweries have at least one piece of equipment that's just a bit persnickity. Here at Boulevard it's fermenter number seven, the black sheep of our cellar family. Ironically, when our brewers were developing variations on a traditional Belgian-style farmhouse ale, the perfect combination of elements came together in that very vessel. You could call it fate, but they called it Tank 7, and so it is. Beginning with a flavorful surge of fruity aromatics and hoppy, grapefruit notes (Amarillo hops), this complex, straw-colored ale finishes long, dry and spicy.

# The Boy's Take

A very traditional Belgian Saison with just a little extra floral hops, and grapefruit citrus notes. As with all the smokestack series this beer is premium in quality and another great traditional Belgian style brew from Boulevard.

# About the Brewer

Boulevard has been a fixture in Kansas City since 1989 and is now a household name in much of the Midwest. In fact, if you're in the Midwest, you won't be able to get away from the ubiquitous (and award-winning) Unfiltered Wheat Beer. Honestly, we think a lot of Boulevard's beers are very Midwestern: not as brash as the West Coast, not as scrappy as the East Coast- just high-quality and presented simply. And it seems to have worked. Founder John McDonald originally planned for 6000 barrels of beer a year in his business plan. Now, the capacity is over 600,000 barrels. I'd say that business plan worked. The two biggest sellers are Unfiltered Wheat and Boulevard Pale Ale, but we encourage you to venture to try a few others, like the Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale, the Double Wide IPA and the Saison-Brett

# Drink this if You Like

Wheat beers, yeasty and fruity beer, Hefeweizens

# Ideal for People who Like

Fairy tales, Midwestern values, Belgian (but not really, Dutch) values

# Drink While You Are

Making the best of a bad situation, making lemonade out of lemons.

# Pair With

Citrus summer salad, Salmon, Grilled chicken, Veggie Burger.

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Brewed at Samuel Smith's small, traditional British brewery with well water (the original well sunk in 1758 is still in use), best barley malt, roasted barley, yeast and aromatic hops. Nut Brown Ale is relatively dry with a rich amber-brown color and nutty flavor derived exclusively from small amounts of dark malt. Brown ales are a specialty of northern England. Fermented in 'stone Yorkshire squares'.

# What you should know

The specific well water in Yorkshire, England helps form the base of this traditional brew. Samuel Smith's "Taddy" brewery is also one of the few that uses the Yorkshire Square method of brewing, which actually separates the wort (the boiled malt) from yeasty foam at the top. Periodically, some of the wort is pumped up into the yeast to feed it. Finally, the wort is drained, leaving the yeast behind, and a fairly bitter wort. Fortunately, there is enough residual yeast to stay back and continue to soften the taste. It's a laborious method, but it seems to work for Samuel Smith's

# The Boys' Take

We love our English traditional style beers and Sam Smith's Nut Brown is a perfect example of the style. malty, smooth, toasty flavors, and a medium plus body is perfect for a fall evening!

# About the Brewer

The original brewery that Samuel Smith started from started in 1758, although it wasn't until a couple of generations has passed when the true brewery started operations in 1847. Shortly after, old Samuel developed his yeast strain, and the brewery still uses it today- one of the longest continuous yeast strains there are. Plus, they still deliver their beer using horses (well, around Yorkshire, at least). There's also a line of over 300 pubs run by Samuel Smith's throughout England. So different, indeed.

# Drink if you Like

English-style, understated dark beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Tradition, horses, buggies, Yorkshire pudding

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a pint at the pub

# Pair With

Meat and potatoes, chocolate

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

# Beer Description

Fermented with wild yeasts and aged in wine barrels with orange peel, Sofie is a tart, dry, sparkling ale. A subtle, spicy white pepper note, a hint of citrus from the orange peel and a creamy vanilla finish make Sofie an intriguing choice for Champagne drinkers and beer drinkers who are fond of Belgian Saisons.

# What you should know

This beer is bottle conditioned with additional yeast added after bottling, but overall it's a pretty simple beer. Farmhouse Ales were originally brewed by famers to attract the best farm hands. This is named for the Granddaughter of Goose Islands founder and will continue developing for up to 5 years.

# The Boy's Take

This effervescent farmhouse ale is crisp with notes of fresh pear. While it is light in body it has a wonderful complexity. An excellent example of a Belgian beer that's made in the US!

# About the Brewer

Goose Island is Chicago's microbrewery, launched in 1988 by founder John Hall, just returned from a European tour. More than just making good craft beer, Hall advocated for it, helping bring consciousness of this new revolution to one of the US's largest cities. This meant growth, and by 1995, it was time for another brewery. Along the way, Hall had built smaller pilot beer labs and 143,000 sqft of barrel space for barrel-aging beers. This was revolutionary, and it got Goose Island its name, especially for the Bourbon Country Barrel-Aged Stout (released once a year on Black Friday and notorious for creating long lines far from the shopping malls). But eventually there was a cap to the growth, and Annheiser-Busch came calling. Yes, Goose Island has been owned by A-B for several years and that has meant‚Ä¶ a lot more Goose Island. Most would agree, the quality of the beer is still top-notch, you just can get Goose Island in a lot more places, thanks to A-B. And there's nothing wrong with that.

# Drink this if You Like

Dubbels, Trippels, Saisons

# Ideal for People who Like

Geese, Golden Eggs, Barrels, Not judging books by their covers

# Drink While You Are

At home in your library, looking out over Lake Michigan, catching a Cubs game

# Pair With

Mussels (and other fresh shellfish), pork belly, Rind Cheeses

# Beer Description

Matilda is made with a rare yeast that suggests a fruity and spicy flavor. There is complex maltiness balanced with a profuse amount of hops.

# What you should know

This beer is bottle conditioned with additional yeast added after bottling, but overall it's a pretty simple beer. The brewer uses beet sugar to feed the yeast after it's inserted in the bottles. This beer will continue developing for up to 5 years.

# The Boy's Take

Chalk this one up to smell's worse than it's bite‚Ä¶ crack it open and we got hit with a blast of all sorts of sweet and fragrant aromas- but the taste is quite a bit drier, maybe even a little bit smoky. She finishes sweet though. Sweet Matilda.

# Beer Description

Four generations of the Moortgat family have brought together Pilsner malts, Bohemian hops, and a unique yeast strain to create this intense, aromatic and beguiling ale. This Belgian favourite is best enjoyed chilled (40 - 50 F) with discerning friends or good-looking strangers.

# What you should know

After bottling, Duvel is bottle-conditioned by adding additional yeast, and the bottles are allowed to rest in the warm brewery cellars. The yeast goes crazy, creating that high alcohol content- but then the bottles are moved to the cold, where the yeast activity slows and the fermentation completes, leaving a crisp, light taste. The name of the beer comes from the Flemish word for "Devil"

# The Boys' Take

Bubbly like champagne but smelling a lot like Belgian yeast, Duvel is lip-smackingly crisp and dry without a lot of bitterness at all

# About the Brewer

Duvel is a Belgian mega-brewer that actually now owns a few American craft brewers. However, since establishment in 1871, they seem to have used their power for niceness instead of evil. The Moortgat family actually started the brewery on their farm, and during WWI, they came into contact with English ales. They liked these so much that head brewer Albert journeyed across Britain until he found a Scottish strain that Brewery Moortgat still uses to this day. After four generations, the Moortgat grandchildren decided to take Duvel across the world and expand its reach- and we're glad you can get it at BrewPublik World Headquarters!

# Drink if you Like

Belgians, Pilseners, Saisons

# Ideal for People who Like

Champagne, cellars, Belgium, family farms

# Drink While You Are

Impressing at a dinner party

alcohol.name: Duvel

# Beer Description

The end of the world. The excellence of triple fermentation through a blend of special yeasts gives this malt beverage an exquisitely robust flavor of exceptional refinement.

# What you should know

As Unibroue is found of mentioning, La Fin du Monde has won more beer festival medals than any other Canadian beer. Like most Belgian ales, the yeast added after bottling will continue to refine the beer. Hold on to it for 3 years for the best possible taste!

# The Boy's Take

Pour this one straight into the bottom of your glass to really let the yeast and medley of flavors play together! Although this smells like it will be pretty fruity, especially cirtrusy, it actually drinks pretty smoothly and ends very crisp and bubbly! It will remind you of a lager, but with a lot more going on, we think.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Pale Ales, Light Belgians and Pilseners

# Ideal for People who Like

Prepping or eagerly awaiting the apocalypse

# Drink While You Are

Avoiding the Four Horsemen, deserving of a reward on a warm day

# Pair With

La Fin du Monde stands up well to salty, full-bodied foods such as blue cheese or salty seafood (mussels, salmon), along with game or sausage

# Beer Description

In November 1992 Maudite (the damned one), was the first strong beer to be distributed in Quebec grocery stores. Maudite is a mahogany-colored, rich-tasting premium beer that has a distinctive, complex taste. Because of the warmth it releases, this strong character beer must be served cool but not cold.
Maudite has a typically Quebecois name that is reminiscent of the legend of the Chasse-Galerie (the legend of the Flying Canoe). Legend has it that a group of lumberjacks struck a deal with the devil to fly home in their canoes, guided by Satan himself, to make it home in time for Christmas.

# What you should know

We guess there is lot of Satanic lore in Quebec- Unibroue's Trois Pistoles is a beer named after a deal cut with the devil as well. This beer is also great for aging, with 5-8 years the ideal age. Over time, the flavors will become smoother and richer.

# The Boy's Take

Perfect for a winter day, we taste a little bit of plum here, followed by some solid malts and just the hint of spice at the end. It will leave you wanting more.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Quads, Strong Belgian Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Lumberjacks, the Devil, Plums, Complicated things

# Drink While You Are

Up the river in a canoe without a paddle, bringing one up from your beer cellar

# Pair With

Gruyere, Spicy dishes, Tomatoes, Grilled Meat, Cr√®me Brulee, Pasta

# Beer Description

Strong Belgian type ale similar to a Port wine. Is as dark as can be, mellow in taste with an aroma of ripe fruits. It can be compared to an old porto and is brewed from well roasted malt.

# What you should know

Trois Pistoles is named after a legend of a small town who recruited Satan (!)- appearing in the form of a black horse- to help them build their village church. This horse, although strong, could not be controlled and the town never finished their church building. Learn something new everyday. But for the record, we are BrewPublik would likely not recommend getting the Devil to build your church. Just doesn't seem like it would work out.

# The Boy's Take

Trois Pistoles is a beer to savor- very full-bodied and chock full of fruit flavor, this beer is well-carbonated but not for quick-drinking. It's rich and sweet and quite enjoyable.

# About the Brewer

Unibroue, in the countryside of Quebec, was the first North American brewery to adapt Belgian Trappist style brewing, and it has paid off. Since being founded in 1992, demand for the Trappist brews has only grown, and Unibroue was purchased first by iconic Canadian brewer Sleeman and then Sleeman was purchased by the mega-brewery Sapporo from Japan. Paul Arnott, the brewmaster, has been trained in monastic brewing tradition and came over straight from Belgium in 2001.

# Drink this if You Like

Trippels, Strong Belgian Ales, Stouts

# Ideal for People who Like

Ancient French Canadian legends, monks

# Drink While You Are

On the verge of deciding to try out hockey,

# Pair With

Chocolate desserts, fruit, rich cheeses

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

The Sculpin IPA is a testament to our humble beginnings as Home Brew Mart. Founded in 1992, the Mart continues to be a catalyst for the San Diego brewing scene, setting the trend for handcrafted ales. Inspired by our customers, employees and brewers, the Sculpin IPA is bright with aromas of apricot, peach, mango and lemon. Its lighter body also brings out the crispness of the hops. This delicious Ballast Point Ale took a Bronze Medal at the 2007 Great American Beer Festival in the Pro Am category. The Sculpin fish has poisonous spikes on its fins that can give a strong sting. Ironically, the meat from a Sculpin is considered some of the most tasty. Something that has a sting but tastes great, sounds like a Ballast Point India Pale Ale.

# What you should know

This beer is hoppy, but doesn't rely on brute force to bring across the delicious. The use of lighter, soft malts (only four varieties) leads to a light body that really showcases the bright hop taste. Unusually, hops are actually added during the mashing process, to give a nice oily feel and taste.

# The Boys' Take

There's a reason a lot of people will say this is literally the best American IPA! The hops are allowed free reign to really show themselves off, and there is so much flavor- mango, grapefruit, pine. Treat this like Skittles. Taste the rainbow.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

Fruity or tropical IPAs, IPAs in general

# Ideal for People who Like

The tropics, fishing, the sunny climes of San Diego

# Drink While You Are

Enduring a brutal winter and wishing you were in San Diego, dealing with a hot summer and wishing you were in San Diego

# Food Pairings

Tropical savory foods (think flavored by coconut), Jerk Chicken, Tropical fruit

# Beer Description

A style of beer curiously born on the foggy shores
of Father Junipero Serra‚Äôs first founding mission. Our own vigorous
entry is one rebellious IPA, quick on the trigger, and brimming with a
bounty of hop ingenuity. This is a big, bold, brazen beer, a restless
vision of a new America.

# The Boy‚Äôs Take

This is a very west coasty double IPA. Plenty of
hops and malt perfectly blending malt sweetness and citrusy goodness. If
you haven‚Äôt tried this one you‚Äôre in for a treat!

# About the Brewer

In 2007, the Mission Brewery opened as one of the
new craft breweries in San Diego. But in 1913, Mission Brewery was a
groundbreaking brewery- the first brewery built in the mission style.
Unfortunately, shortly after, Prohibition hit- and surprisingly the
amazing non-alcoholic soda Hopski failed to save the brewery.
Fortunately, 80 years later, the name and ‚Äúmission‚Äù was revived. Dan
Sells got it restarted, and soon he needed the space to move into a
historic Wonder Bread facility in downtown San Diego. Mission sticks to
more commonplace styles but has a solid style of each. We recommend the
Dark Seas Imperial Stout and also their Pils and Helles lagers.

# Drink this if You Like

Double IPAs, Imperial IPA, IPA

# Ideal for People who Like

Shipwrecks, architecture

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying 24/7 sun, sailing the open seas,
channeling your inner conquistador

# Pair With

Chimichangas, Pad Thai, Mango Chutney.

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description:  

An honest to goodness India Pale Ale brewed with a bevy of real citrus including orange peel, lemon flesh & blood orange juice.

# What you should know: 

Tropical fruit included as an ingredient in IPAs is sooooo the rage in 2016.  The sugars in the fruit provide extra food for the yeast but still stay around, no longer sweet but still flavorful.

# The Boys‚Äô Take: 

If there‚Äôs a more refreshing summer beer, we‚Äôd like to hear it. Of course, tons of fruit and pith- it almost feels like there is grapefruit pulp in there.  And there are still hops, don‚Äôt worry

# About the Brewer:  

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role.  Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry. The key to a good double IPA is all about balance and this brings the hops and the malt it a copious way that balances well. We would definitely go out of our way to grab one of these!

Uinta is in a bit of a strange situation. One of our favorite IPAs, with a sweetness from rye malt and Mosaic hops (which contribute no sugar but bring the illusion of fruity sweetness).  Then of course, it finishes quite bitter.

Perhaps you heard of a worldwide beer-movement
that tributes favorite hipster neighbourhoods across the globe. First
came Istedgade, Copenhagen then S√∂dermalm, Stockholm followed by
Williamsburg, New York and Shoreditch, London accompanied by Trastevere,
Rome & last El Raval, Barcelona. If you feel excluded because you‚Äôre hip
but your city is not, this cutting-edge, ‚Äòhip without borders‚Äô pale ale
is an homage to you ‚Äì the global hipster. Cheers!

# The Boys‚Äô Take

Usually known for doing everything to the extreme,
Evil Twin has really toned it down with this really solid pale ale. With
a great balance of bready malts and floral and citrus hops this is a
great beer for any occasion. 

# About the Brewer

Evil Twin is unique. It‚Äôs a gypsy brewery, meaning
it develops the recipes, but uses breweries across the world to actually
make the beer. This means it isn‚Äôt committed to a solid list of beers
that it makes at its brewery. It bounces around from one to the another,

they release year-round. Check out their website
([www.eviltwin.dk](http://www.eviltwin.dk)) - I mean, there are tons of

cool yet.

# Beer Description

The elusive brew is made from pilsner malt and amber malt with an original gravity of 26.5?P, yielding an 11% abv. It's hopped with Warrior and Glacier varieties. Primary fermentation takes place in open vessels using two yeast strains, one American and one English. For added complexity, the beer is conditioned on barrel staves of French Oak for four months before being dry hopped with Glacier at the rate of a half-pound per barrel. This elixir is then blended 50/50 with 90 Minute IPA. After blending, the beer will measure 80 IBU and 10% abv.

# What you should know

So this beer is actually a mix of the Dogfish Head 90-Minute IPA recipe and a Glacier-hopped amber cocktail that is aged on French Oak barrels. Glacier hops are a variant of the original English-style hops, but there here to contribute more flavor than bitterness, as the 90-Minute IPA brings more than enough of that to the table.

# The Boys' Take

Imagine the deliciousness of Dogfish Head 90-minute, but with a huge boozy, malty base to play with,. This one starts big and boozy and bitter before finishing up with some really interesting caramel and vanilla notes. This is something you've got to try

# About the Brewer

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role. But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names. 90-Minute IPA is the more extreme version of one of Dogfish's signature brews (the 60-minute IPA). If you like this beer, try the 60-minute for session drinking or the Burton Baton for a full experience.

Big Belgians, barrel-aged beer, stouts, Imperial IPAs

The fact that we said Big Belgians above, sipping beer, everything oaked

Sitting in a big leather chair, smoking a cigar

Toasted nuts, peanut sauce, spicy food

# Beer Description

Midas Touch Golden Elixir is a beverage based on the residue found on the drinking vessels in King Midas' tomb. Our recipe highlights the known ingredients of barley, white Muscat grapes, honey and saffron. Somehwere between a beer, wine and mead, this smooth, dry ale will please with Chardonnay or I.P.A. drinker alike.

# What you should know

Dogfish Head is a little nutty. The brewery has been working with biomolecular archaeologist Dr. Patrick McGovern to research ancient brewing habits. Well, when Dr. McGovern worked with the team that uncovered the tomb of King Midas, Unbelievably, there was still residue from the king's last feast on vessels buried with him. Well of course, that means it was time to copy the recipe! What resulted from this craziness is Midas Touch

# The Boys' Take

What a fascinating beer! It's sweet, tart, and unlike many beers, actually tastes a little like grapes. The first sips taste of white wine, followed by some malty toasted flavor, maybe even some strawberry jam? I mean, if you're going to drink like a king, might as well drink like King Midas!

# About the Brewer

Dogfish Head Brewery sees itself as the maverick in an already free-spirited industry, and relishes this role. Founder Sam Calagione started the brewery in Milton, DE in 1995 and now spends much time on television discussing the craft beer industry. In fact, at least on the east coast, it's hard to avoid DFH- there's a hotel, a tv show and even sausages for heaven's sake! But they do make amazing beer, often with unique flavor combinations and even stranger names.

# Drink this if You Like

White wine, pale beers, Belgian beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Science! Archaeology, Ancient Greece

# Drink While You Are

Debating the classics, enjoying book club

# Pair With

Asian dishes, risotto, curry, baked fish + chicken

# Beer Description

Affiliated with the Nectar Ales experience through
shared origins at Humboldt Brewing Company, Hemp Ale is a one-of-a-kind
brew that boasts an incredibly rich profile and unique herb-accented
flavor that is attributable to the incorporation of hemp seeds into the
brewing process. A wonderful brown ale full of complexity Hemp Ale is
great with food or by itself. American hops create a perfect balance to
the darker malts used in this brew. This brown ale is the Gold Medal
winner for first place in its category at both the 1999 and 2000
California State Fair Craft Brewing Competitions

# The Boys‚Äô Take

Rosty and dark with just enough body for a brown
ale Humboldt‚Äôs brown ale is right on the money. Notes of chocolate, nut,
and caramel malts a really solid brown ale.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be
all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft
microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern
California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their
carbon footprint, and who doesn‚Äôt love that? In 2005, the little
Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total
Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale
after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex,
malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Brown Ales, Porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

# Beer Description

A smooth, full-bodied nut brown ale, lightly
hopped with a hint of roasted and crystal malts. This ale is dark in
color without the heavy taste of porter or stout.

# What you should know

Brown Ales originated in England, where ales
with the dark brown malts started to appear in the in 1700s. The
original brown ales struggled against pale malts, which were more
efficient in brewing. However, the style came back in the end of the
19^th^ century and then became a mainstay in the new American craft
brewing.

# The Boys‚Äô Take

Man, this is good! Chocolate, vanilla, and a hint
of nuttiness all combine and for a smooth, easy-drinking and flat-out
delicious beer.

# About the Brewer

The Lost Coast Brewery and Caf√© began with a
dream. In 1986 Barbara Groom, a pharmacist wondered what it would
require to start a brewpub. After years honing her skills home brewing,
planning and studying scores of pubs throughout England & Wales Barbara
was ready to transform the dream into a reality. Since its humble
beginning in 1990, the brewery has outgrown not just its original
facility in the Pythian Castle, but has also outgrown the site it moved
to in 1993 just down the street. After a long successful 25 years and
breaking two production records in 2005 with 24,000 barrels, and 2009
with over 50,000 barrels, the brewery is now located at the south end of
Eureka, California in a brand new state of the art facility. Barbara
Groom designed it to not only make exceptional brews in, but to be open
for the public to enjoy as well, opening Summer 2015. Currently the new
facility is brewing at a 90,000-barrel capacity and is still working to
brew to greater heights!

# Drink this if You Like

Smooth beers, milk stouts, brown ales

# Ideal for People who Like

City life, Taxi rides, painting the town

# Drink While You Are

Out on the town, Taking in the city

# Pair With

Roasted meat, spicy meat, ancho chilis, chipotle

# Beer Description

Boasting a ruby hue and an exquisite floral aroma, Red Nectar is a robust yet elegant brew with distinctive accents of toasted malt, caramel, spice and residual sweetness. The beer that started it all‚Ä¶ Red Nectar was considered a strange bird when it was first released in 1987. After all, where did a robust, handcrafted all-natural amber ale fit into the massive flock of American industrial lagers? Answer: it didn't. So it blazed its own trail, helping set the pace for the craft brew revolution. Enjoy Red Nectar for its dazzling reddish copper hue, original flavors and caramel spice accents

# The Boys' Take

Flavorful, tasty and malty. This one starts sweet with the smell and the taste- maybe a little bit like a snack of fruit, then there's a spice taste. Finally, you may feel some slight fruity hops hit the back of your throat. Amber ales are normally a relatively tame bunch, but this one has some complexity.

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their carbon footprint, and who doesn't love that? In 2005, the little Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex, malty beers from these nature lovers!

Amber ales, porters, doppelbocks, smooth-drinking beer

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Beer Description

Like FDR's Depression-Era Radio Addresses, which were like a kick in the butt and a hug at the same time, our Fireside Chat is a subtle twist on the traditional seasonal brew. We begin with a rich, dark, English-style ale and then we improvise with spices until we know we have a beer worth sharing with the nation. Celebrating the right to be original.

# What You Should Know

Winter warmers are generally characterized by big malt flavor, and a wide variety of spices (more a feature of American interpretations rather than the original English style). They also typically carry higher alcohol content. Fireside Chat is brewed with a delicious medley of spices and also cocoa nibs to give a slight chocolate flavor.

# The Boys' Take

Ask Zach about this beer, and he'll tell you it's dope! An office favorite, Fireside Chat is rich, but without being overpowering and the mix of spices is just delightful.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious. They just have the advantage of pulling it off maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

Dark ales, Winter warmers, Strong ales

# Ideal for People who Like

World War II, Christmas spices, mulled cider, a cozy blanket

# Drink While You Are

Wanting to be Zach's friend, listening to the radio

# Pair With

An aperitif, dessert

# Beer Description

Aged for three months in Wild Turkey Bourbon barrels, this luxurious stout has a deep ebony hue and a beautiful mahogany head. The woody, vanilla-like notes imparted by the barrels mingle with aromas of fresh baked bread, toffee, and espresso and envelop the rich chocolate and roasted barley flavors with a fine bourbon character. Our exclusive partnership with Wild Turkey gives Anderson Valley a world class, consistent source of barrelage, allowing our brewers to explore new frontiers in barrel-aged craft beer.

# What you should know

Barrel-aging is a tradition going back to pre-Prohibition days. Way before breweries were the space-age industrial things that they are today, beer was aged in good-ole wooden barrels. The cool thing is that the beer will actually take on the character both of the wood and the previous occupant of the barrel. In addition, various microorganisms in the barrel mix with the yeast already in the brew and have a real party, leading to a beer that is wonderfully bourbon flavored and more complex than usual.

# The Boy's Take

This is a manly drink. Just say the word bourbon and our mouths start to water, but we're a beer company, so naturally we keep the Anderson Valley version around to keep ourselves satisfied. This is good stuff, people.

# About the Brewer

Ahh, Anderson Valley, in beautiful, pastoral Booneville, CA, using solarpower and pixie-dust to create some of the best-drinking, smoothest ales around. The original brewery was in the basement of a brewpub run by Ken Allen, and beer operations started in earnest way back in 1987. After really killing it for a few years, Ken moved to a huge, gleaming brewhouse in the middle of nowhere in Northern Cali. Well, in 2010 Ken did retire, leaving the company to Trey White, who partnered with brewmaster Fal Allen (no relation to Ken). Since then Trey and Fal have taken Anderson Valley national and jumped whole-heartedly into seasonal and barrel-aging scene. Try the Hop Ottin IPA and the Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

# Drink this if You Like

Bourbon, stouts, rich porters

# Ideal for People who Like

Solar energy, the woods, Wild Turkey

# Drink While You Are

Relaxing, in a cabin in the woods

# Pair With

Beef sliders, pork tacos, in a beer float

# Beer Description

A medium-bodied pale ale with a beautiful copper color, a robust head, and the rich flavor of caramel malt.

# What you should know

Boontling is a language used on every Anderson Valley Brewing labels. Spoken by the inhabitants of the Anderson Valley, of which Boonville is the largest town. Boonville was an isolated farming and logging town during the late 1800's. There are a couple different stories about the origin of Boontling. Some say that the language was created by the women, children, and young men in the hop fields and farmlands as a means of entertainment, and that it spread through the region as the kids continued using it when they grew up.

# The Boy's Take

Amber ales are one of those beer styles it's hard to do wrong but Anderson Valley true to form has produced one of the best Amber Ale's around! Not too heavy with caramel maltiness and just a hint of floral hops. A prefect easy drinker.

# About the Brewer

# Beer Description

A rich, copper ale with a case full of gold medals. Our Calico Amber Ale takes its inspiration from traditional English ESBs. Four types of malts give it a bold complexity, and our proprietary yeast strain lends it a fruity, madeira-like richness. However, it‚Äôs the American hops that give this ale a distinct bite and floral aroma that have earned it just about every major beer medal.

# The Boys' Take

If you‚Äôre an amber ale drinker this might be a little more then you bargained for. If you love an IPA but are looking for something a little meltier this is your beer. A traditional amber ale with the hops of an IPA and the beautiful amber complexion of an easier drinker it doesn‚Äôt get much more balanced than this! 

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers.  Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene.  Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world.  As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out.  Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born.   Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea.

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Pale Ales, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Coronado, Something a little bit extra.

# Drink While You Are

Eating sushi, resting after kiteboarding

# Pair With

Sweet Hawaiian fish, mango chutney burger, Hawaiian BBQ.

# Beer Description

Rare Vos is flemmish for "Sly Fox," and the name of one of Brussels' great cafes. It has a sweetly fruity malt character and yeasty spiciness. A fine dose of yeast permits the beer to mature and mellow in the bottle.

# What you should know

The name is inspired by the caf√©s (such as Rare Vos) that serve these soft, yeasty amber ales all throughout Belgium. This one of the maltier brews on offer for Ommegang and features Styrian Goulding hops.

# The Boys' Take

Rare Vos will remind you a little of cherries and other dark fruit as you sip it, but not in an overpowering way. Most of the flavors are mellow and soft, with the yeast flavor definitely still shining through. It remains light throughout and finishes dry. Sorta like a gassed water you might be given at a Flemish caf√©.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions. The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY. Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition). Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery. In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast. Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US. In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink if you Like

Dubbels, lambics, Amber ales

# Ideal for People who Like

European cafes and checkered tablecloths, San Pellegrino

# Drink While You Are

Eating moules frites or Belgian waffles, seeking a sophisticated beverage.

# Pair With

Cheese, rich desserts, risotto, mustard greens, chili

Our Evil Twin is only bad because it is too good to resist.

# Beer Description

This beautiful, deep russet brew has the sweet and somewhat nutty character of Adam Avery's late (1992-2002) Chocolate Lab, for which it is named. Crystal and chocolate malts give this beer a brown sugar maltiness with hints of vanilla and nuts, while subtle hopping gives it an overall drinkability that's second to none, just like Ellie!

# What you Should Now

Brown Ales originated in England, where ales with the dark brown malts started to appear in the in 1700s. The original brown ales struggled against pale malts, which were more efficient in brewing. However, the style came back in the end of the 19th century and then became a mainstay in the new American craft brewing.

# The Boys' Take

Man, this is good! Chocolate, vanilla, and a hint of nuttiness all combine and for a smooth, easy-drinking and flat-out delicious beer.

# About the Brewer

Adam Avery started Avery Brewery in 1993 in Boulder, CO. It was bold at the time to open a brewery, and Avery started small. However, now today is established solidly as a quality brewer out of the brewery mecca of Denver/Boulder. Avery is committed to making original beer‚Ä¶ and not just what everybody wants. This means that it hasn't had the same commercial success, but also means it gets to keep a solid reputation with the experts. Some of the best aggressive beers come from here- especially the seasonal Dictator series- which contains traditional classic styles on steroids. If like a drop-kick to the face of fresh hops in the springtime, check out The Maharaja- an Imperial IPA.

# Drink this if You Like

Smooth beers, milk stouts, brown ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Man's best friend, chocolate

# Drink While You Are

Playing fetch, or scooping poop

# Pair With

Roasted meat, spicy meat, ancho chilis, chipotle

# Beer Description:  

Brewed in collaboration with Sebastien Sauer of Freigeist, this malty beer was inspired by our Westfalia but brewed with smoked malts and charred manzanita

# BREWPUBLIK's Take:

We aren't scared off but the hint of smoke here- what you have is a drinkable, slightly sweet amber that gets just a bit of extra complexity from the added smokiness

# Beer Description

Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale represents a time honored tradition of brewing a special beer for the holiday season. There are generous portions of barley malts and fine whole hops of several varieties, creating a brew with a full, rich and hearty character.

# What you should know

So it says right there on the Sierra Nevada website that the vast majority of hops are grown August through October. To celebrate. Sierra Nevada brews an aggressive, hop-forward ale using a lot of those hops fresh from the harvest. The Cascade and Centennial hops bring the citrus flavor and then finally Chinook comes in with the piney taste and aroma.

# The Boy's Take

You'll smell all those fresh hops right away with the grapefruit aroma and taste them right away too. This is rare in a Christmas beer to have such strong, sharp flavor, but it feels like a perfect celebration of the new hops that just came in. Merry Christmas.

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980. From the beginning, Sierra Nevada beer has been a celebration of spicy American hops, and they've never backed down from that. And they've earned their upper-tier position by forging a path that in 1980 barely existed. Hops were hard to find. Brewery equipment didn't come on a micro scale. Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream. Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop. Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC. To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes.

# Drink this if You Like

The smell and taste of hops, bitter pales, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Farm-to-bottle, things being as fresh as possible, hops

# Drink While You Are

Standing under the mistletoe, taking a break from the Christmas punch

# Pair With

Fish and chips, Turkey, Polenta, Grilled Veggies, Dry/Sharp cheese

# Beer Description:  

An instant classic, Union Jack is the recipient of numerous awards including back to back wins at the Great American Beer Festival. Union Jack is abound with hop aroma and character. In fact this well balanced, west coast IPA is dry hopped 3 separate times, each lot giving it more and more of the grapefruit citrus hop aroma and flavor it is known for. Overall it utilizes over 4 pounds of pacific northwest hops per barrel.

# The Boys‚Äô Take: 

This is a Californian IPA. Bright auburn color, some sweet malts and then the rich, tangy flavors of pine and citrus- tasty!

# About the Brewer:  

Firestone Walker is located in Paso Robles, California a location more known for its wine production than its brewing. Started in 1996 by brother-in-laws Adam Firestone (yes he‚Äôs from the Firestone tire family) and David Walker, Firestone Walker is one of the biggest breweries in California. Firestone walkerowns another brewery, Humboldt Brewing, and is partially owned by Duvel Brewing from Belgium.

# Drink if you Like: 

IPAs, fruit-forward beers

Breezes, palm trees, the crash of the waves on the shore

Going to your happy place

# Beer Description

Torpedo is an assertive American IPA deep reddish-gold in color, with a smooth and bready malt presence and over-the-top hop aromas. The beer has a solid bitterness and a massive hop flavor, yet remains easy drinking with a pleasant dry finish.

# What you should know

"The Hop-Torpedo" is a revolutionary dry-hopping device that controls how much hop aroma is imparted into beer without adding additional bitterness. Torpedo Extra IPA is the first beer Sierra Nevada created using this system.

# The Boy's Take

This is Extra IPA is definatly a tweener not quite a DIPA a little bit more than a standard IPA but 100% great hop-forward perfection!

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980. Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream. Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop. Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC. To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes.

IPAs, DIPA's

Maritime Ordnance, Fresh Pine Scent.

Watching "The Hunt For Red October"

# Beer Description

Wonderful complex flavos, like no other, simply a great tasting IPA. It's balanced, strong malt backbone, citrusy nose, with hints of pine and grass.

# What you should know

Uinta originally named this beer "Hop Notch"- meaning still unknown to us- but quickly ran into trademark trouble and had to change the name to Hop Nosh (which actually makes more sense to us, as you are "noshing" on some hops with this drink).

# The Boy's Take

Where the guys at Uinta get this is right is by provide a solid backbone of malt to hold up the mostly citrusy hops. You'll taste bitterness midway through this drink, and then at the end, it'll be a bit of earthy, roasty taste (just a bit). And you'll want another.

# About the Brewer

Uinta is in a bit of a strange situation. A successful craft brewer since 1993, Uinta brews a variety of amazing beers, but is based in Salt Lake City, Utah- a state where only beers under 4% ABV are allowed in grocery stores (anything else is treated like liquor). This means that the biggest brewery in the state doesn't even sell a single can in grocery stores in the state! Anyway, Uinta has done a great job despite that obstacle and is well known for well-crafted (often high-grav) beers that are respectful of style while still pushing the envelope. Especially recommended are their IPAs such as Hop Nosh, Dubhe DIPA and Labyrinth Black Ale

# Drink this if You Like

Citrusy, well-balanced IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

The finer points of trademark law, Utah, vegetarian snacks

# Drink While You Are

Feeling parched, losing an argument

# Pair With

Party food, salsa, cheeseburgers

# Beer Description

Back in Black is our newest year-round beer available now in six pack cans and on draft. Brewed like an American IPA but with the addition of rich, dark malts, this beer has all the flavor and hop character you expect with a smooth, mellow finish.

# About the Brewer

It's the brewer that puts its beer in cans! 21st Amendment makes beer in those little stubby guys, and it stands out in the midst of rows of bottles, They also made the very fortuitous decision to bring craft beer to South Park, in the epicenter of San Francisco urban revival. These factors make 21st Amendment one of the coolest. For some reason, there's just nothing like beer in a can. Similar to many other brewers, 21st focuses on themes of freedom and originality- but ironically, their beer is similar to many other west-coast brewers- aggressive, inventive, and delicious, They just have the advantage of pulling it maybe a bit better than anyone else.

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs plus a rich, dark taste, stouts, IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

AC/DC, the original Coke, being cool, the "darker side" of things

# Drink While You Are

Trying to stand out, feeling cold but still wanting an IPA

# Pair With

Red meat, BBQ ribs, Burgers, Shepherd's Pie, Wheat Pancakes (why not!)

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Malt and hops are beautifully married in this full-bodied, copper-red Pale Ale. Red Seal Ale is generously hopped in the traditional manner for a long, spicy finish.

# What you should know

Pale ales grew up as a term for the strongest ales carried in English pubs. More than other English beers, lighter malts in the pale ale allowed hops to do most of the talking. The copper malts in Red Seal Ale give it a dry, toasted feel, extenuating the punch that the bitter hops bring.

# The Boy's Take

The darker malts in this beer make us lean more towards a hoppy amber ale, but who are we to argue with North Coast? The malts here are slightly sweet, and the hops aren't overwhelming but instead nicely balanced and herby, which balances quite well with the more robust body. We like it.

# About the Brewer

North Coast brewing is a veteran in the craft beer scene. In 2015, they don't care about being cool, trendy or buzz-worthy. Just a group of craftsmen concentrating on making excellent beer. We might suggest a slight update to the website, but we don't suppose these guys care. Mark Ruedrich started North Coast in 1988 on the picturesque Mendocino coast (north of San Francisco), just down Hwy 1 from Mendocino brewing. Mark doesn't seem to be about flashy new releases, fancy labels and hot styles. Instead, North Coast has a broad range, one that hasn't changed much in years (although more recently NCB has resurrected the old ACME brewing label from 1800's San Francisco). You may know the Old Rasputin Imperial Stout. Drink that, but we also recommend Old Stock Ale and the Old No. 38 Stout.

# Drink this if You Like

Amber Ales, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Pacific sea mammals, whiskers, Sea World

# Drink While You Are

Sitting on a rocky beach, sun bathing, avoiding Killer Whales

# Pair With

Quesadillas, salsa, steak and other red meat, spinach salad, andouille

# Beer Description

If you have fallen for the IPA style like we have, Big Eye will be a welcome addition to your repertoire. You'll revel in Big Eye's bitter, hoppy flavor thanks to the American Columbus and Centennial hops that are used to flavor and dry hop our flagship IPA. We thank our hops every day that the English loved their bitters‚Äîor else the IPA style may not have been born to help the beer survive the journey from Cape Hope to India back in the 18th century

# What you should know

This is your traditional American West Coast IPA- lots of Columbus hops flavor and then dry-hopping with Centennial. Centennial hops are one of our favorites- a nice piney smell and citrusy taste.

# The Boys' Take

Not flashy, so solid. A really nice body of malts holds up the floral tastes that we are desperately seeking. Due to the Centennial dry-hopping, we get a lot of grassy and flowery flavor here.

# About the Brewer

Ballast Point, out of San Diego, started as a small group of home brewers who just wanted to try some new beers. Their constant thirst for experimentation and exploration has now grown to one of the giants of the massive San Diego brewing scene. Their M-O is to constantly tinker, try to release new options, look at things from new angles and make room for themselves in what can be a crowded craft beer world. As a side note, they also distill liquor- so check that out. Founder Jack White started with just a homebrew kit at his house in 1992, and by 1996, the brewery had been born. Today, they make just about every style, with favorites being the IPAs Sculpin, Big Eye, Dorado Double and the porter, Victory at Sea

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, Double IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

San Diego, Coronado, Grapefruit, the smell of freshly-cut grass

# Drink While You Are

Eating sushi, resting after kiteboarding

# Food Pairings

Sweet Hawaiian fish, Curry, Cured meat

# Beer Description

Named after Coronado Island, our original India Pale Ale is a liquid expression of hometown pride. Cascade, Chinook, and Columbus hops combine to provide an explosive burst of piney bitterness and lucioius notes of apricot, grapefruit, and mango that are sure to envoke imagery of swinging palms and sun-kissed shores.

# What You Should Know

The Islander IPA swings for a tropical home run. All three of the C's (the hop varieties used here) come with a fruity, juicy taste.

# The Boy's Take

This one is sweeter than most IPAs, with a light body that does surprisingly well to not taste like alcohol at 7%. A the finish, it really does carry a little bit like a nice Tequila Sunrise, with some citrusy sweetness.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America's greatest beach (Coronado) and their first keg delivery was straight to the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000 barrels a year, and we can't wait for an ever-greater selection to be available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit, the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Drink this if You Like

West Coast IPAs, Tropical Drinks

# Ideal for People who Like

Mojitos, Pina Coladas, Sunbathing

# Drink While You Are

Finding your beach, doing some California Dreaming

# Food Pairings

Curried food, Thai food, peppery cheese, sharp cheddar

# Beer Description

Our Red IPA has full-bodied flavor from ample Pale
malts while specialty malts provide a deep ruby hue. El Dorado hops are
used for their tropical fruit flavors. It‚Äôs then dry-hopped with
additional El Dorado hops for a delicious fruity aroma, making it
perfect for unwinding with friends. Read that? Beer nerd.

# About the Brewer

The Lost Coast Brewery and Caf√© began with a
dream. In 1986 Barbara Groom, a pharmacist wondered what it would
require to start a brewpub. After years honing her skills home brewing,
planning and studying scores of pubs throughout England & Wales Barbara
was ready to transform the dream into a reality.

Since its humble beginning in 1990, the brewery has outgrown not just
its original facility in the Pythian Castle, but has also outgrown the
site it moved to in 1993 just down the street. After a long successful
25 years and breaking two production records in 2005 with 24,000
barrels, and 2009 with over 50,000 barrels, the brewery is now located
at the south end of Eureka, California in a brand new state of the art
facility. Barbara Groom designed it to not only make exceptional brews
in, but to be open for the public to enjoy as well, opening Summer 2015.
Currently the new facility is brewing at a 90,000-barrel capacity and is
still working to brew to greater heights!

# Drink this if You Like

IPAs, West Coast IPAs, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Exploring, Gold, the color red

# Drink While You Are

Lost, Shopping for compasses or maps

# Pair With

Chicken Pesto Tacos, Thai or Indian cuisine

# Beer Description

Our IPA is created from a base of Pale and Crystal malts and is aggressively hopped throughout the brewing process with a final hop addition in the conditioning vessel. A beautiful flowery hop aroma will greet you as you dive into this hop lover's dream. A middle caramel malt presence balances high hop bitterness with hop flavor end to end... learn to love hops! (Editor's Note: originally brewed by Humboldt Brewing Company under the name "Humboldt IPA Nectar" until their acquisition by Firestone Walker.)

# The Boys' Take

A really great west coast style IPA. The name says it all with nectar fruit notes a kiss of hop bitterness and some beautiful floral aromas if you like a good IPA you'll love this one!

# About the Brewer

These guys made the first hemp beer. That might be all you need to know about Humboldt. One of the first craft microbreweries, Humboldt started way back in 1987 in northern California. They live at peace with nature and generally minimize their carbon footprint, and who doesn't love that? In 2005, the little Humboldt brewery was bought by Firestone Walker, and then by Total Beverage Solutions. For a while, it was actually known as Nectar Ale after the flagship Red Nectar ale. For the most part, look for complex, malty beers from these nature lovers!

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales, IPAs, DIPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Hummingbirds, honey whiskey, nature

# Drink While You Are

Enjoying a picnic, refilling your bird feeder

# Pair With

Spicy BBQ, Hot Wings, Braised Pork Tenderloin
alcohol.name: Nectar IPA

alcohol.description:
# Beer Description

Originally brewed in 1975 to commemorate Paul Revere's ride, this brew is a heavily hopped ale (Cascade hops) with a copper color and a hoppy nose.

# What You Should Know

Liberty Ale is single hopped and dry-hopped, two concepts that were revolutionary in 1975 when this beer first appeared. Then the beer is aged in casks with bungs to promote natural carbonation.

# The Boys' Take

Is this a Pale Ale? Is it an IPA? Since this one was invented sooo early, it sorta defies classification as either. It was a true trend-setter with its emphasis on dry-hopping. It's not going to be too bitter, but does have a nice kick to it. Real grapefruity!

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Drink this if You Like

Pale Ales and IPAs

# Ideal for People who Like

Originality, tradition, the best beer to come out of the 70s

# Drink While You Are

Celebrating being American, or being a blacksmith, or riding horses at midnight

# Pair With

Chicken, nutty cheeses, salad, fish, Italian, BBQ

# Beer Description:  

In the San Francisco spirit of innovation, Villager blends classic Northwest hops with contemporary ale yeast to establish a delicately constructed IPA. Villager's hop aroma is both citrusy and floral, complemented by notes of stone fruit and tropical favor in the finish. A true expression of the cultural contrasts that embody our city by the bay, Villager brings a new twist to this West Coast style.

# The Boys‚Äô Take:  

The nice thing about this beer is that it‚Äôs brewed with a view- a stunning one from Fort Point‚Äôs brewhouse in the Presidio, San Francisco.  And we think that a better view can actually make a better beer. Hoppy, but not overwhelming, Villager is a really refreshing, fresh-tasting IPA that will scratch that hop-head itch you know you have.

# About the Brewer:  

Fort Point Beer Company was founded in 2014 by Tyler and Justin Catalana. Fort Point is really proud to be a San Francisco brewery and that pride is reflected in their beer. The brewery is located in the Presidio in a historic building that once housed an Army motor pool. You can also visit their tap room located at the Ferry Building. Great beer shape and strong roots make Fort Point a truly San Francisco original.

# Beer Description: 

There is no beautifier of complexion, or form, or behavior, like the wish to scatter joy and not pain around us. Crisp Lager has nothing to hide behind - no makeup to cover up any flaws. Raw ingredients and their essence, full and unabated...uninhibited...CRISP

# What You Need to Know: 

Pilseners originated in the Czech Republic, believe it or not, but once the style was adopted to Germany, the German brewers slightly adopted the style to have a bit more body and show a bit less spicy hops. Sixpoints doesn‚Äôt define which style they‚Äôre aiming for, but we tend to think of this more like a Czech pils.

# The Boys‚Äô Take: 

Super dry and refreshing, with a pleasant burst of hopiness at the end.  Balanced, but with a suprising amount of hops in there.

# About the Brewer:  

Sixpoint Brewing is legit, and our Chief Design Officer, Sam loves their website. Plus, they have those Red Bull-style, thinner cans, which is different. Andrew Brownstein and Shane Welch hail from Brooklyn, although much of the beer is brewed upstate. They came on the scene in 2004 and the skinny cans came in 2011.  What‚Äôs in the logo, you ask? It‚Äôs a mixture of a hexagram and a nautical star.

# Drink this if You Like: 

Lagers, German styles, Pilsners

# Ideal for People who Like:  

Wafers, freshly cleaned sheets

# Drink While You Are: 

Travelling the German-Czech border

# Pair With: 

Potato wedges, fried chicken, caprese salad

of orange peel and coriander flavor and a malty finish.

# About the Brewer

Coronado Brewery is proud of its San Diego island
roots. The brewhouse itself was right there on what maybe America‚Äôs

the Hotel Del Coronado. From the beginning, brothers Ron and Rick
Chapman have been focused on brewing truly west-coast style ales- look
for bold, fresh taste. Their brewing capacity is now close to 60,000
barrels a year, and we can‚Äôt wait for an ever-greater selection to be
available here on the Right Coast. For now, look for the Orange Ave Wit,
the Islander IPA and Idiot IPA (lots of hops)

# Beer Description

Robust and smooth, this full-flavored lager is exceptionably drinkable and pitch black in color.

# What you should know

The emphasis for Schwarzbiers is on dark, roasted malts, mixed with lager yeast, meaning when you get a Schwarzbier, you're really looking at straight malt- no crazy yeast esters and very little bitterness. The earliest documented beer of this type is from 1543, and it's still made in many places in E Germany today.

# The Boy's Take

Smooth and chocolately, Baba has long been an easy-drinking favorite of ours at HQ. We get chocolate and little bit of woodiness and maybe a little bit of that umami taste you get from soy sauce, the one that makes you want it so much.

# About the Brewer

Uinta is in a bit of a strange situation. A successful craft brewer since 1993, Uinta brews a variety of amazing beers, but is based in Salt Lake City, Utah- a state where only beers under 4% ABV are allowed in grocery stores (anything else is treated like liquor). This means that the biggest brewery in the state doesn't even sell a single can in grocery stores in the state! Anyway, Uinta has done a great job despite that obstacle and is well known for well-crafted (often high-grav) beers that are respectful of style while still pushing the envelope. Especially recommended are their IPAs such as Hop Nosh, Dubhe DIPA and Labyrinth Black Ale

# Drink this if You Like

Porters, dark lagers

# Ideal for People who Like

Black sheep, bags of wool, black coffee, chocolate

# Drink While You Are

Hanging out with your boy Schwartz (we know, not quite perfect, but‚Ä¶), trying to be smooth

# Pair With

Rich barbeque, Mexican, dark bread, pretzels, marinated meat

# Beer Description

Wheat ale made with natural mango flavor.

# The Boys‚Äô Take

Light and crisp with just a hint of mango fruitiness. It‚Äôs the perfect summer brew if you‚Äôre looking for something just a little different!

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing.  Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today.  Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries).  The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air.  To be honest, we‚Äôre not sure what effect that has.  But it most do something.  Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat.  The original copper brewing equipment is still there.  The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Beer Description

Our first lager produced with the 20 bbl brewhouse. This pilsner is a clear golden color. Four additions of Saaz hops lend a spicy-floral hop component.

# What You Need to Know

Both German and Czech styles of pilsener developed as rivals in Europe, and although Germans are known more for their pilseners, we'd venture to say that the Czech version has done pretty well for itself all on its own.

# The Boy's Take

This one is all-malt, no additives of corn or rice to water this down, and you can tell- there's real flavor here.

# About the Brewer

Oskar Blues is quickly becoming a North Carolina favorite, in large part due to the fact that they opened a second base of operations near Asheville recently. This means their beer is even fresher than ever before, with the cans having to travel just two short hours down 74 to Charlotte. Although their beer is easy to miss in the little cans, Oskar Blues has generated quite a following and are ready to celebrate their 12th anniversary in 2014 (the original brewery is in tiny Lyons, CO)

# Beer Description

Samuel Adams Boston Lager¬Æ is the best example of the fundamental characteristics of a great beer, offering a full, rich flavor that is both balanced and complex. It is brewed using a decoction mash, a time consuming, traditional four vessel brewing process discarded by many contemporary brewers. This process brings forth a rich sweetness from the malt that makes it well worth the effort. Samuel Adams Boston Lager¬Æ also uses only the finest of ingredients including two row barley, as well as German Noble aroma hops. The exclusive use of two row barley not only imparts a full, smooth body but also gives the beer a wide spectrum of malt flavor ranging from slightly sweet to caramel to slightly roasted. The Noble hops varieties, Hallertau Mittelfruh and Tettnang Tettnanger, add a wide range of floral, piney and citrus notes, which are present from the aroma, through the flavor, to the lingering smooth finish. We take great pride in the Noble hops used in our beers. They are hand selected by Jim Koch and our other brewers from the world's oldest hops growing area. Among the world's most expensive, they cost twenty times as much as other hops.

# What you should know

This was the beer that some say started it all. It was Boston Beer (Sam Adams) very first beer, and one of the first that lead the revolution of using the highest quality ingredients and brewed to a premium quality.

# The Boys' Take

It's been such a long time, it's easy to overlook the old Boston Lager, but there's something to be said for the straight-forward, traditional taste of the beer that "started it all"

# About the Brewer

Boston Beer (aka Sam Adams) is the 300-pound gorilla in any craft beer conversation. In fact, the official definition of "craft beer" was changed in 2010 to make sure Sam Adams was considered craft beer, when they first brewed more than 2 million barrels. Their 2013 revenues were more than 3 times the second-biggest brewer. So yeah, we're talking a different ball game. This makes Sam Adams a divisive topic in the craft beer world. If you listen to Boston Beer, they are still a great innovator and help open a bigger market for craft beer with their big budget and TV ad campaigns. If you ask the hopheads, they are an unimaginative, lumbering giant that deserves to be treated like one of the big boys. We still think they make good beer, and if we know you'll like it, we'll bring you some

# Drink if you Like

Lagers, old school beers, easy-drinking beers

# Ideal for People who Like

Oldies but goodies, the 80s, American patriots

# Drink While You Are

Planning a tea party perhaps?

# Pair With

BBQ, ribs, calamari

# Beer Description

Gather your friends, pack the gear, and head out to wherever the day may take you. A midday go-to, Nooner is our take on the classic German-style pilsner‚Äîone of the original session beers. Nooner is easy drinking yet packed with the big flavor of spicy and floral whole-cone hops. Its brilliant golden color begs you to take a sip and sink your taste buds into an extremely welcoming beer, full of flavor and balanced by a crisp, dry finish.

# The Boy's Take

This here is a quality pilsener. Not spicy or bitey, it's quality-made, with just a little bit of malt to hold everything together. Generally, the taste is very dry

# About the Brewer

The third-largest craft brewer in the US, Sierra Nevada has proven that it belongs at the very top of the rankings since 1980. From the beginning, Sierra Nevada beer has been a celebration of spicy American hops, and they've never backed down from that. And they've earned their upper-tier position by forging a path that in 1980 barely existed. Hops were hard to find. Brewery equipment didn't come on a micro scale. Then they came up with the Pale Ale, which was instrumental in bringing the West Coast style to the mainstream. Finally in 1987, Sierra Nevada moved into downtown Chico and setup shop. Now they are a N. California fixture and also have a brewery in the works in Asheville, NC. To this day, Sierra Nevada is still synonymous with hoppy, fresh beer, and we hope that never changes.

# Drink this if You Like

Pilseners, golden ales

# Ideal for People who Like

A mid-day break, lazy Sundays, deck chairs

# Drink While You Are

Gearing up for an adventure

# Beer Description

Anchor Steam¬Æ Beer owes its deep amber color, thick, creamy head, and rich, distinctive flavor to a historic brewing process like none other. It is a process that combines deep respect for craft brewing tradition with many decades of evolution to arrive at a unique approach: a blend of pale and caramel malts, fermentation with lager yeast at warmer ale temperatures in shallow open-air fermenters, and gentle carbonation in our cellars through an all-natural process called kr√§usening.

# What You Should Know

The open-air fermentation process leads to a flavor complexity and a taste different really from any other beer.

# The Boys' Take

Much like steam, this one is thin and light- but it has a stiff bite. You'll definitely taste both barley and hops here.

# About the Brewer

Anchor Steam beer is puritanical in their pursuit in time-honored methods of brewing. Established in the 19th century, Anchor somehow managed to survive the Prohibition and kept on brewing in San Francisco until today. Their most famous beer is the Steam Beer, which is distinguished by being brewed in open air tanks (rather than tall vertical tanks used by other breweries). The hot wort is only cooled by steam from San Francisco air. To be honest, we're not sure what effect that has. But it most do something. Anyway, a trip to Anchor is a real treat. The original copper brewing equipment is still there. The tiny little original brewery is still there. Overall, a really cool brewery with a reputation for quality.

# Beer Description

Ommegang Witte, a traditional Belgian-style wheat ale with whispers of sweet orange and a touch of tart lemon. Soft and seductive.

# What You Should Know

A very highly rated Witbeir. If you like Blue Moon, you‚Äôll love this. Brewed in the Belgian-style, so be sure to look for the Orange peel and coriander flavors. Serve in a tumbler or a weizen.

# About the Brewer

Ommegang is a farmstead brewery completely fashion after old-school Belgian traditions.  The brewery is actually situated in the middle of an old hops farm in Cooperstown, NY.  Cooperstown, the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame now, used to also be home to the largest hop-growing area in the US (pre-prohibition).  Anyway, with the help of Duvel (a Belgian brewing conglomerate), the farmhouse was built in 1997, In 2003, Duvel went ahead and purchased the brewery.   In brewing premium Belgian ales, Ommegang draws on the special water available in the area, imported Bavarian hops and their own house yeast.  Together, all these ingredients lead to a very impressive combination of Belgians brewed in the US.  In fact, the Hennepin Saison was the very first Saison brewed in the US and help resurrect a style that was in danger of dying.

# Drink this if You Like

Blue Moon, Witbeirs, Wheat Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Soft and seductive beers, Traditional recipes 

# Drink While You Are

Touring the baseball hall of fame, Pruning citrus trees

# Pair With

Steamed Mussels, Chicken Piccata, Veal Parmesan

# Beer Description

While this beer is light in color, it's not lacking in flavor. This easy drinking beer has fruity and floral notes with a clean finish. A healthy dose of wheat malt adds to the complexity you would expect from a blonde.

# What You Need to Know

The Blonde ale is actually a creation of American craft brewers to explain a less-extensively hopped, but still pale, ale made traditionally in England. Used to light lagers, American drinkers quickly took to this maltier style- and then Blonde Ales found their way back to England as a style all their own!

# The Boys' Take

Tip a few of these back- they're easy to drink! The taste is mostly malt, with some floral hop flavor, but nothing too crazy

# About the Brewer

Fortnight is definitely the total hybrid of English sensibilities and, well, America. The brewery is drab and unassuming, but walk in, and there is tons of room- high ceilings and space to breathe (something you don't see in many pubs). But the magnificent wooden bar is there, with a couple of casks perched for on-the-spot infusions and aging. Yes, Fortnight is very much a representation of, well, England, and all its beers fill that mold. Now, English beers are not like American ones- they are typically lower in both alcohol and complexity, but no less care is used in making them. The good thing is that you can have five while watching soccer and get away with it. The team, a collection of beer-lovers drawn to the Raleigh-Durham area by various corporate jobs, founded the brewery only recently- but bring a mixture of organization and ambition that has Fortnight on the right track, we just know it.

# Drink this if You Like

English beer, Blonde Ales, Kolsch, Pale Ales

# Ideal for People who Like

Blondes over Brunettes, Having more fun

# Drink While You Are

Enduring a rainy day, in a red phone booth, eating kidney pie
